Erik Wilde: Error Messages for HTTP APIs: Standards, Patterns, and Practices

(2) Summary

Reporting errors is a fundamental aspect of API design. The way it's done can differ between APIs, API technologies, and API styles, but since it is a very common pattern it makes sense to not reinvent the wheel for every single API. We look at how to report errors in HTTP APIs but the lessons learned in this session can be applied to other technologies and styles as well. Beyond the format there also is the question which patterns to apply so that API designers get as much support as possible from their platform when it comes to managing the error messages of their APIs. The format that we discuss is a successor of the popular RFC 7807 error format. We'll discuss why there is a new version, what the changes are, and how to best use it in your APIs and your API landscape.



Erik Wilde: Error Messages for HTTP APIs: Standards, Patterns, and Practices

APIs, Guidelines, and Governance Erik Wilde: Error Messages for HTTP APIs: Standards, Patterns, and Practices

(5) API as Interfaces

  • APIs are technical interfaces
  • APIs should use information hiding [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_hiding]
  • APIs are built on a foundation of styles and technologies


APIs, Guidelines, and Governance Erik Wilde: Error Messages for HTTP APIs: Standards, Patterns, and Practices

(6) API as Products

  • Good API design goes outside-in starting from consumer needs
  • Good products minimizing the cognitive load of consumers
  • API designers should focus on business logic concerns
  • API platforms are supporting API producers


APIs, Guidelines, and Governance Erik Wilde: Error Messages for HTTP APIs: Standards, Patterns, and Practices

(7) What is an Effective Team?

  • A team spending less time with generic API-related tasks
    • Figuring out the general guardrails for API design
    • Designing, implementing, exposing, securing, and monitoring APIs
    • Deploying APIs and making them discoverable for consumers
  • A team spending more time addressing domain issues
    • Engaging with consumers and designing a good API
    • Making sure that consumer feedback is collected and used
    • Contributing to the shared API practices of the organization


APIs, Guidelines, and Governance Erik Wilde: Error Messages for HTTP APIs: Standards, Patterns, and Practices

(8) API Guidelines

  • More API teams mean more ways to solve the same problem
    • Solving API problems is not what teams should focus on
    • Solving API problems in a consistent way helps the API landscape
      • Why does the guideline exist?
      • What can be done to address the described issue
      • How to implement the solution
      • Testing that the guideline has been followed


    APIs, Guidelines, and Governance Erik Wilde: Error Messages for HTTP APIs: Standards, Patterns, and Practices

    (9) API Guideline in the Wild



    APIs, Guidelines, and Governance Erik Wilde: Error Messages for HTTP APIs: Standards, Patterns, and Practices

    (10) API Governance

    • Balancing coherence and autonomy in large organizations
    • Making it easy to do the right thing
    • Making it hard to do things wrong
    • Using tools, processes, and platforms to engineer the engineers

    HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Error Messages for HTTP APIs: Standards, Patterns, and Practices

    (12) HTTP Problem Details

    • HTTP status codes [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-status-code/] are useful but minimalistic
      • Their well-defined semantics allow intermediaries to act on them
      • Servers may want to convey additional information with them
    • APIs may include problem details as part of their representation designs
      • Using a standard reduces the design work on the server side
      • Using a standard allows developers to more easily understand the design
      • Using a standard allows problem details analysis across APIs
    • RFC 7807 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html]/9457 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html] defines a JSON-centric model for problem details
      • application/problem+json is a JSON-based representation of the problem detail model
      • application/problem+xml is an XML-based representation of the problem detail model


    HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Error Messages for HTTP APIs: Standards, Patterns, and Practices

    (13) HTTP Problem Details: JSON 

    {
  "type": "https://example.com/probs/out-of-credit",
  "title": "You do not have enough credit.",
  "detail": "Your current balance is 30, but that costs 50.",
  "instance": "/account/12345/msgs/abc",
  "balance": 30,
  "accounts": [
    "/account/12345",
    "/account/67890"
  ]
}
    • http-problem-details.json


    HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Error Messages for HTTP APIs: Standards, Patterns, and Practices

    (14) HTTP Problem Details: XML 

    <problem xmlns="urn:ietf:rfc:7807">
  <type>https://example.com/probs/out-of-credit</type>
  <title>You do not have enough credit.</title>
  <detail>Your current balance is 30, but that costs 50.</detail>
  <instance>https://example.net/account/12345/msgs/abc</instance>
  <balance>30</balance>
  <accounts>
    <i>https://example.net/account/12345</i>
    <i>https://example.net/account/67890</i>
  </accounts>
</problem>
    • http-problem-details.xml

    RFC 9457: The New RFC 7804 Erik Wilde: Error Messages for HTTP APIs: Standards, Patterns, and Practices

    (18) Differences between RFC 7807 and RFC 9457

    • There are no breaking changes
    • Three issues seen from usage in the wild
      • Registry of common problem type URIs
      • Clarification of how to treat multiple problems
      • Guidance for using type URIs that cannot be dereferenced

    (24) Shift left? Shift up!

    • Product people: Raise an issue when inventing patterns
    • Platform people: Identify the biggest bang for the reuse buck
    • Tooling people: Bake open and extensible patterns into tools
